53959945017.description:
Sensō-ji is a historical marvel in Asakusa, Tokyo, known as the oldest temple in the city, with its origins dating back to 645 AD. This Buddhist temple, dedicated to the bodhisattva Kannon, has withstood the test of time, including the destruction during World War II and subsequent reconstruction, symbolizing resilience and peace. 

Its rich history is intertwined with the cultural fabric of Tokyo, attracting millions of visitors each year who come to admire its architecture, including the iconic Kaminarimon gate and the five-story pagoda.
53959945017.title: Sensō-ji

54061593979.description:
Nakamise-dōri street leading up to the Sensō-ji Buddhist temple in Asakusa, Tokyo. 

There has been a temple on the site since 645 AD however this incarnation has been around since the 1950s onwards, the original having been destroyed during an American air raid on the night of 9/10 March 1945.
54061593979.title: Tokyo   |   Sensō-ji

54114391969.description: This is the pagoda at the Buddhist temple Sensō-ji in Asakusa, Tokyo. It is built in a classical style - but actually dates to 1973. There has been a pagoda on the temple grounds since the 17th century, so it is part of an old tradition. ⓒRebecca Bugge, All Rights Reserved Do not use without permission.
54114391969.title: Sensō-ji pagoda

54116324786.title: Passer montanus saturatus

54180046600.title: Get more blessed @Senso-ji.

54181068357.description:
Asakusa is a vibrant district in Tokyo, known for its rich history and traditional atmosphere. It's home to the famous Sensō-ji Temple, Tokyo's oldest temple, and is a place where visitors can enjoy a sense of the Tokyo of past decades. The area is also renowned for its numerous festivals, including the Sanja Matsuri, one of Tokyo's most spectacular and popular events. 

Asakusa offers a unique blend of cultural experiences, from exploring ancient temples to shopping for traditional goods along the Nakamise-dori street.
54181068357.title: Asakusa

54181069687.description:
Asakusa Shrine, also known as Asakusa Jinja or Sanja-sama, is a significant Shinto shrine located in the Asakusa district of Tokyo, Japan. Established in 1649, it honors the three men who founded the Sensō-ji Temple, which is the oldest temple in Tokyo. 

The shrine is a rare example of early Edo architecture and has been designated an Important Cultural Property, having survived the air raids of World War II. It is also the focal point of the Sanja Matsuri, one of Tokyo's most important festivals held annually in late May.
54181069687.title: Asakusa Jinja

54181071327.description:
Asakusa is a vibrant district in Tokyo, known for its rich history and traditional atmosphere. It's home to the famous Sensō-ji Temple, Tokyo's oldest temple, and is a place where visitors can enjoy a sense of the Tokyo of past decades. The area is also renowned for its numerous festivals, including the Sanja Matsuri, one of Tokyo's most spectacular and popular events. 

Asakusa offers a unique blend of cultural experiences, from exploring ancient temples to shopping for traditional goods along the Nakamise-dori street.
54181071327.title: Asakusa

54181071682.description:
Sensō-ji is a historical marvel in Asakusa, Tokyo, known as the oldest temple in the city, with its origins dating back to 645 AD. This Buddhist temple, dedicated to the bodhisattva Kannon, has withstood the test of time, including the destruction during World War II and subsequent reconstruction, symbolizing resilience and peace. 

Its rich history is intertwined with the cultural fabric of Tokyo, attracting millions of visitors each year who come to admire its architecture, including the iconic Kaminarimon gate and the five-story pagoda.
54181071682.title: Sensō-ji

54181073682.description:
The Yogodo hall, part of the historic Senso-ji Temple complex in Tokyo, is a significant site for Buddhists who worship the goddess Kannon. Built in 1994, it houses eight Buddhas and is nestled within the oldest Buddhist temple in Tokyo, dating back to the 7th century. 

This temple, a centerpiece in the Asakusa district, not only reflects the rich history and culture of the Edo era but also stands as a testament to the resilience and restoration efforts following natural and wartime damages.
54181073682.title: Yogodo

54181077722.description:

54181077722.title: Sensō-ji

54181953746.description:
Asakusa is a vibrant district in Tokyo, known for its rich history and traditional atmosphere. It's home to the famous Sensō-ji Temple, Tokyo's oldest temple, and is a place where visitors can enjoy a sense of the Tokyo of past decades. The area is also renowned for its numerous festivals, including the Sanja Matsuri, one of Tokyo's most spectacular and popular events. 

Asakusa offers a unique blend of cultural experiences, from exploring ancient temples to shopping for traditional goods along the Nakamise-dori street.
54181953746.title: Asakusa

54182166438.title: Praying

54182235393.description:
Asakusa Shrine, also known as Asakusa Jinja or Sanja-sama, is a significant Shinto shrine located in the Asakusa district of Tokyo, Japan. Established in 1649, it honors the three men who founded the Sensō-ji Temple, which is the oldest temple in Tokyo. 

The shrine is a rare example of early Edo architecture and has been designated an Important Cultural Property, having survived the air raids of World War II. It is also the focal point of the Sanja Matsuri, one of Tokyo's most important festivals held annually in late May.
54182235393.title: Asakusa Shrine

54182238554.description:
The Hozomon Gate is a historically significant structure located in Asakusa, Tokyo, Japan. It serves as the inner of two large entrance gates leading to the Sensō-ji Temple, the oldest temple in Tokyo. This imposing gate, also known as the "Treasure-House Gate," houses many of the temple's treasures on its second story, including a copy of the Lotus Sutra, a Japanese National Treasure. 

The Hozomon Gate has been rebuilt several times throughout history, with the current structure dating back to 1964, designed to be fire-resistant to protect the precious artifacts it holds.
54182238554.title: Hozomon Gate

54198844791.description: Onigawara are decorative features found most often on Buddhist temple roofs, though sometimes also on shrines or residences. Kawara is the word for ceramic roof tiles that were introduced into Japan along with Buddhism and temple architecture from the Korean Peninsula in the 6th century during the Asuka Period of Japanese history. The word oni is somewhat more problematical to translate, with the word demon most often used, but in English the word demon has connotations of evil, whereas the Japanese oni does behave in evil ways, it is also capable of acting for good, so the word ogre is perhaps better. Sometimes the word goblin is also used, though that word is often associated with another class of mythical creature called a Tengu. The simplest translation though is probably "demon tile". Onigawara are found at the ends of the main roof ridge, the Ohmune, and at the ends of the descending ridges, the Kudarimune, and their practical purpose is to protect against weathering, and though primarily made of ceramic, stone or wood is not unknown. Up to the Heian Period (794-1185) they were decorated with designs of flowers or animals, but from the Kamakura Period (1185-1332) the Oni design came to prominence. Their spiritual function is to ward off evil, and so they have sometimes become associated with the European gargoyle. While onigawara are almost always Oni, there are some of other creatures, including Tengu and Kappa. As well as Onigawara there are other types of decoration on temple roofs, the most well known being the Shachi, or Shachihoko, the mythical creature with the body of a fish and the head of a tiger. These are placed on top of the main ridge and are to ward of fires. Big Shachi often covered in gold leaf will be found on top of Japanese castles. Other than the shachi there are various other figures found on roofs including komainu, phoenixes, monkeys, doves, etc. Being ceramic, onigawara will often survive the periodic fires that tend to burn down temples and other wooden buildings in Japan and so older examples can often be found on display around the grounds of a temple or in the temple's treasure house. Near Sensoji Temple | Asakusa, Taito-ku, Tokyo
54198844791.title: 鬼瓦 Onigawara
